document.docAuthor: Rodrigues, Everton Nei Lopes & Brescovit, Antonio D.
document.docTitle: Thymoites piratini Rodrigues & Brescovit, 2015, new species
document.masterDocTitle: On the spider genus Thymoites in the Neotropical Region (Araneae, Theridiidae): nine new species, complementary descriptions and new records

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On the spider genus Thymoites in the Neotropical Region (Araneae, Theridiidae): nine new species, complementary descriptions and new records

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 31–35.
Thymoites camaqua
n. sp.
: 31–33, Male: 31, Palp, ventral. 32, Body, dorsal view. 33, Body, lateral view. 34–35, Epigynum: 34, Ventral. 35, Dorsal, cleared. Scale bars, 0.25 mm.

FIGURES 36–40.
Thymoites piratini
n. sp.
: 36–38, Male: 36, Palp, ventral. 37, Body, dorsal view. 38, Body, lateral view. 39– 40, Epigynum: 39, Ventral. 40, Dorsal, cleared. Scale bars, 0.25 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The specific name is a noun in apposition taken from the type locality.

Diagnosis. The male of
Thymoites piratini
new species differs from those of the other species by the pointed distal area of the carapace ( Figs. 37, 38 ,
61–66
) and the palp with cymbium with pointed apex ( Fig. 36 ,
68– 70
).The female of
Thymoites piratini
new species is close to
Thymoites ilhabela
new species , but differs by the shorter fertilization ducts (
Fig. 40
) and the shape of copulatory ducts ( Figs. 39, 40 ).

Female paratype
(same locality as male,
MCN 52009
): Total length 1.38 . Carapace length 0.65 , width 0.56 . Clypeus height 0.16 . Sternum length 0.35 , width 0.37 . Abdomen length 0.84 , width 0.77 , height 0.79 . Leg formula I/IV/II/III; segment length (I/II/III/IV): femora 0.54 / 0.44 / 0.37 / 0.54 ; patellae + tibiae 0.56 / 0.44 / 0.37 / 0.52 ; metatarsi + tarsi 0.67 / 0.54 / 0.52 / 0.60 ; total 1.77 / 1.42 / 1.26 / 1.66 . Carapace red brown, anteriorly dark brown. Eyes as in male. Endites and chelicerae dark red brown. Sternum red brown, darkened borders. Legs red brown. Abdomen pale yellow, posteriorly dark brown; venter dark brown. Spinnerets yellow brown. Epigynum ( Figs. 71, 72 ) with elongated spermathecae, fertilization ducts shorter and copulatory ducts sinuous ( Figs. 39, 40 ).
